It seems that the US attracts two types of immigrants:
 
 1. The poor from the third world - mainly from Central and South America - who view the even limited opportunities in the US as much better than what they had in their home countries.
 
 2. Entrepreneurs who view the US as a place where an enterprising individual can earn more than he/she can in their own countries. I knew an engineer who immigrated to the US from Sweden for precisely this reason.
 
 The US is no longer as attractive a place to immigrate for the rest of the world's Middle Class. After all, one needs a strong incentive to immigrate - leaving ones home, relatives, leaving the familiar. The US holds little advantage for average Middle Class people of the world - most of whom also live in relative freedom with reasonable opportunities for growth in their own countries. While the US once clearly had obvious advantages in wealth and political freedoms, much of the rest of the world has caught up or is catching up. So, the differences that once drew so many to the US have significantly diminished - making the US less attractive a place for the non-desperate.
